column1: Following the 1881 construction of the New Orleans and Northeastern Railroad through the area
column2: economic development occurred rapidly. The city of Laurel was incorporated in 1882
column3: with timber as the impetus. Yellow pine forests in the region fueled the industry. The city was named for laurel thickets near the original town site.John Kamper built Laurel's first mill
column4: which was small and primitive. On the verge of bankruptcy in 1891
column5: Kamper sold the mill and extensive land holdings
column10: lumber barons Lauren Chase Eastman and George and Silas Gardiner. In 1893
column11: the Eastman-Gardiner mill opened and employed the best technology and labor-saving devices of the day. This mill was followed by the Gilchrist-Fordney mill from Alpena
column17: and the Marathon mill from Memphis
column20: Laurel shipped more yellow pine than any other location in the entire world. The peak of lumber prosperity was reached in the 1920s
column21: when the area's four mills were producing a total of one million board feet of lumber per day – enough laid end to end to stretch 189 miles.The economic prosperity of Laurel's timber era (1893–1937) and "timber families" created the famed Laurel Central Historic District as a byproduct. The area is considered the largest
column23: and most intact collection of the early 20th century architecture in Mississippi and has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places since September 4
column25: for both its history and wide variety of architectural styles. Many of the homes and buildings of the district are featured on the HGTV series Home Town. In addition to influencing a diverse architectural district
column26: the "timber families" influenced the building of broad avenues
column28: and the development of strong schools.

column1: The city population grew markedly during the early 20th century because rural people were attracted to manufacturing jobs and the economic takeoff of Masonite International. Mechanization of agriculture reduced the number of farming jobs. In 1942
column3: a 45-year-old African-American man who had been convicted of murder
column4: was dragged from jail and lynched by a mob. The city reached its peak of population in 1960
column5: and has declined about one third since then.

column1: Laurel is in north-central Jones County
column3: the first county seat. Interstate 59 and U.S. Route 11 pass through Laurel
column4: both highways leading southwest 30 miles (48 km) to Hattiesburg and northeast 57 miles (92 km) to Meridian. U.S. Route 84 passes through the south side of the city
column5: leading east 30 miles (48 km) to Waynesboro and west 27 miles (43 km) to Collins. Mississippi Highway 15 passes through the south and west sides of the city
column6: leading northwest 24 miles (39 km) to Bay Springs and southeast 28 miles (45 km) to Richton.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: Laurel has a total area of 16.5 square miles (42.8 km2)
column3: of which 15.8 square miles (40.8 km2) are land and 0.3 square miles (0.8 km2)
column5: are water. The city lies on a low ridge between Tallahala Creek to the east and Tallahoma Creek to the west. Tallahoma Creek joins Tallahala Creek south of Laurel
column6: and Tallahala Creek continues south to join the Leaf River
column7: part of the Pascagoula River watershed.

column1: The climate in this area is characterized by hot
column2: humid summers and generally mild to cool winters. According to the Köppen Climate Classification system
column3: Laurel has a humid subtropical climate
column4: abbreviated "Cfa" on climate maps. The area is also prone to tornadoes. On December 28
column6: an F3 tornado tore directly through the city
